b'Lucretia,I am so deeply sorry for your devastating loss of your Mum.
The pain is so all consuming every breathe we take, ever tick of the clock is a horror.
Our world stops.
Everything is unreal and surreal.
I understand, I think.
It feels like our life has come apart at the seams and fallen into broken and shattered pieces.

We feel so completely lost.The next few days there will be rituals and arrangements to be made and we muddle thro them blindly, pale and weak.We gather together for services and sharing meals.Then what?My dear Lu, I PROMISE you this: the day will come when it will not be your first waking realization or thought.Slowly, over time, we come to terms that they live within us.
As long as we live they are not gone, we carry them in our hearts and minds.
And we continue to love them.Know that this takes time, far too long but please make this promise to yourself as a friend requested of me: Do not let this destroy you.
I hung onto that promise like a life raft when things were overwhelming.I, too, am going to light a candle for you and keep you in my heart.PM me anytime about anything, I care about you.'

Are you getting support from the MH team, or from your cpn / psych?
And from your aunt?"

I know going to the funeral seems really scary, as is the thought of completely breaking down.

Obviously I don't know what is best for you, but I think being at the funeral is an important part of saying goodbye and being able to grieve together with your family, as hard as it is, can also be helpful.

I remember when my cousin was murdered, going to the funeral home for the viewing the day before the funeral--I was terrified, but it was important for me to go because it was part of grasping the reality of his death, and part of saying goodbye."

really do hope you find the strengh to go and say farwell...love to you xx"
b"It is natural for people to break down at funerals of important people and I have done this.

You may feel overwhelmingly thankful that you were given such a wonderful mum because not many get a good one sadly.
You didn't have her for long enough but you were so lucky to have had a good one.
If you can't go that is ok but I think it'll be good to be with others, not just for yourself but maybe the others need you too.

i vowed i'd never try it again.

b'what do you mean we have to come back to the same lessons?its

b"All IMO - My view is that we're spiritual Beings, a Soul, having a human experience - incarnated into a body/the physical realm.
To my understanding the spiritual realms are far more real than 'normal' waking consciousness.
What is most likely i think is that we incarnate through a large number of lives; learning, experiencing & growing as we go, until we graduate from the need to incarnate.
You will see your mum again on the other side when it's time to go.

People that end things prematurely i think do face great disappointment on the other side & i do think the same lessons/general circumstances have to be faced again in another life, or number of them.If all that is true (which i think it is) - isn't it better to make the most of the opportunities & life you already have?"
b"There is always a choice - there are always a number of free will choices in the vast majority of circumstances.
It's Not punishment - imo it's the way reality works & the reality of the incarnational path/cycle.
There is no Hell (in any religious sense).

i think suicide is very understandable, especially in cases of genuine severe mental illness, But that doesn't, imo negate what i see as the facts/realities of it all.This physical existence i think is the closest thing there is to hell (for some people/souls) - But there is also an element of what we create here, we do have a degree of personal responsibility & accountability."
b"You misunderstand me.
If you do pass over from your own hand you will very likely see the soul of your mum & many others.
i'm just saying there will likely also be disappointment & the reality of coming back with very similar lessons.
i don't see a judgement with it all.

i was totally determined to take my life at the age of 21 & saw no other option - it was a miracle i failed in that attempt, it wasn't my time, & was in fact a very cathartic & profound life changing experience - there is the possibility that happens for you too?
Not that i'd recommend trying it for that potential."

b"My cat had fleas a few months back.

She'd get a flea tablet, they kill all the fells on the animal in a few hours.
They literally just drop off, but some drop off alive and recover.
To fix this, and any eggs or larvae in my carpets, I salted my carpets.
It kills fleas too.
They need 50% humidity to survive.
You have to be careful not to let your carpets get damp, because it will take the moisture out of the air.
I'd say if your house is quite humid, leave it for 24 hours.
I left mine for 2 days.
My carpets got a little damp but once I hoovered up all the salt it dried out.
It'll clog your hoover a little, but I really worked.
I also put warm water on a plate, with a squirt of washing up liquid and a candle in the middle.
The warmth and light will attract the fleas, and they'll jump in the water and get dragged down by the washing up liquid.
It's a great way to monitor your flea population.
If you're worried about a fire hazard, use the LED ones, they'll still get attracted to it.
I use hot water in my flea traps.
This together worked beautifully.
I've seen one in the last 3 weeks, and we were infested.
It was bad.
Hoovering is another brilliant weapon against fleas, as long as you remember to empty your hoover and put the waste outside.
